item.title: Comment on WordPress Pretty Permalinks with Nginx by Gwyneth Llewelyn
item.dc:creator: Gwyneth Llewelyn
item.description:
Mmh I know... it's been over a decade ago when this must-use plugin snippet was first launched... since then, I've been religiously copying it to all my websites running WP over nginx.
After all these years, I wonder if the underlying issue has been 'fixed' by Automattic at the WP core level? In other words — is this 'pretty permalinks' workaround for nginx still necessary, on contemporary (uh, 2021) versions of WP/nginx?
I'm just curious — leaving the must-use plugin around seems not to have any harmful effect, so, unless told otherwise, I'll keep it there...
item.content:encoded:
Mmh I know… it’s been over a decade ago when this must-use plugin snippet was first launched… since then, I’ve been religiously copying it to all my websites running WP over nginx.

After all these years, I wonder if the underlying issue has been ‘fixed’ by Automattic at the WP core level? In other words — is this ‘pretty permalinks’ workaround for nginx still necessary, on contemporary (uh, 2021) versions of WP/nginx?

I’m just curious — leaving the must-use plugin around seems not to have any harmful effect, so, unless told otherwise, I’ll keep it there…

item.title: Comment on Ignore Phone Calls From Vivint by Stuey
item.dc:creator: Stuey
item.description: Vivint has averaged three calls a day to my house. I look at caller ID and never answer. I am on the do not call list, but obviously they circumvent the list. Finally blocked their number after their third call today! They are relentless. They even learned to han up after the second ring so they don't have to listen to the voice message.
item.content:encoded:
Vivint has averaged three calls a day to my house. I look at caller ID and never answer. I am on the do not call list, but obviously they circumvent the list.
Finally blocked their number after their third call today! They are relentless. They even learned to han up after the second ring so they don’t have to listen to the voice message.

item.title: Comment on Fractions of a Penny by Tom
item.dc:creator: Tom
item.description: Totally incorrect and kinda naieve. Thought it was pretty common knowledge the 9/10 was purely for the psychological effect of seeing a lower number for the price. Also, You pay what you pay. Skimming a fraction of a sale is called theft. Most cards can be charged fractions. Since the practice of 9/10 is quite a bit older than credit cards.
item.content:encoded: Totally incorrect and kinda naieve. Thought it was pretty common knowledge the 9/10 was purely for the psychological effect of seeing a lower number for the price. Also, You pay what you pay. Skimming a fraction of a sale is called theft. Most cards can be charged fractions. Since the practice of 9/10 is quite a bit older than credit cards.

item.title: Comment on Utah Vaccination Math by Utah Vaccination Trends – Joseph Scott
item.dc:creator: Utah Vaccination Trends – Joseph Scott
item.description: […] rough math for number of vaccines Utah needs to be giving each day was 15,000. Unfortunately https://coronavirus-dashboard.utah.gov/#vaccines only provides the total […]
item.content:encoded: […] rough math for number of vaccines Utah needs to be giving each day was 15,000. Unfortunately https://coronavirus-dashboard.utah.gov/#vaccines only provides the total […]

item.title: Comment on Utah Vaccination Math by josephscott
item.dc:creator: josephscott
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/2021/01/01/utah-vaccination-math/#comment-238570">Publius</a>.
This is definitely a time for all hands on deck. Another metric that would point to how we are doing: the time between when a vaccine shipment is received and when it is given. Until we are over this pandemic I would be expect that to be 5 days or less.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Publius.

This is definitely a time for all hands on deck. Another metric that would point to how we are doing: the time between when a vaccine shipment is received and when it is given. Until we are over this pandemic I would be expect that to be 5 days or less.

item.title: Comment on Utah Vaccination Math by Publius
item.dc:creator: Publius
item.description: Thank you, this is worthwhile bringing to everyone's attention (and comports with my own calculations.) Given that every infection could result in death, 1 in every 200 known Utah infections have died so far, and we're experiencing over 2,000 known new cases per day, we are likely to see hundreds more Covid deaths. The vaccination part of preventing these deaths couldn't be more important. I'm with those demanding all deliberate speed including 24/7 administration of the shots. Gov-elect Cox and Director Saunders must see that it happens. Any delay whatever is unconscionable.
item.content:encoded: Thank you, this is worthwhile bringing to everyone’s attention (and comports with my own calculations.) Given that every infection could result in death, 1 in every 200 known Utah infections have died so far, and we’re experiencing over 2,000 known new cases per day, we are likely to see hundreds more Covid deaths. The vaccination part of preventing these deaths couldn’t be more important. I’m with those demanding all deliberate speed including 24/7 administration of the shots. Gov-elect Cox and Director Saunders must see that it happens. Any delay whatever is unconscionable.

item.title: Comment on Safari Is Working On Native Lazy-Loading Images by josephscott
item.dc:creator: josephscott
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/2019/09/30/safari-is-working-on-native-lazy-loading-images/#comment-234875">Denny</a>.
Safari has an option for it, under <code>Develop > Experimental Features > Lazy Image Loading</code>. I haven't heard anything about when that would be promoted to a regular option ( enabled by default ).
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Denny.

Safari has an option for it, under Develop > Experimental Features > Lazy Image Loading. I haven’t heard anything about when that would be promoted to a regular option ( enabled by default ).

item.title: Comment on Have I Done Any Good by josephscott

item.content:encoded:
In reply to 青山.

I’d agree, reflection is key to growth as a person.

item.title: Comment on Safari Is Working On Native Lazy-Loading Images by Denny
item.dc:creator: Denny
item.description: One Year later. Nothing happens. Chrome and Firefox work, Safari not. Bad thing.
item.content:encoded: One Year later. Nothing happens. Chrome and Firefox work, Safari not. Bad thing.

item.title: Comment on Have I Done Any Good by 青山
item.dc:creator: 青山
item.description: I also think it's important to reflect on what you've done right and what you've done wrong every day, so you can see what you've gained and what you've lost, and that's important for our growth. I'm a college student from China, and I've built my own blog using wordpress.
item.content:encoded:
I also think it’s important to reflect on what you’ve done right and what you’ve done wrong every day, so you can see what you’ve gained and what you’ve lost, and that’s important for our growth.
I’m a college student from China, and I’ve built my own blog using wordpress.
